Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff Jasmine Reed (“Plaintiff”) brings this action against Defendant Mark Thompson (“Defendant”) for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, codified at Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this case arises under the landlord-tenant relationship and pertains to a residential lease within Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to the terms of the lease agreement and G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant, as landlord, is obligated to provide Plaintiff with quiet enjoyment of the premises, which includes maintaining heat at a safe and habitable level during winter months in accordance with the Massachusetts Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.201).

105 CMR 410.201.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide adequate heat violates the Massachusetts Sanitary Code regulation requiring landlords to maintain a minimum temperature of 68 degrees Fahrenheit in residential units during winter months. See 105 CMR 410.201.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982) (breach of quiet enjoyment occurs when landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” under Massachusetts law and explains that liability arises from serious interferences with the tenant’s tenancy, focusing on the landlord’s acts or omissions and their natural and probable consequences. While it does not use the exact words “substantially interfere,” it adopts that concept by defining quiet enjoyment as freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises and by holding the landlord liable where repeated flooding interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Thus the case supports the stated formulation of breach of quiet enjoyment as substantial interference with use and enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … The jury found in answer to a special question … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Failure to make necessary repairs constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The court recognizes that there is an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that protects a tenant from serious interference with the tenancy, and that a landlord who, with notice, negligently fails to alleviate a condition can be liable. However, on the facts, the court holds there was no breach because the landlord acted promptly and repaired the conditions. The opinion therefore does not stand for the general proposition that failure to make necessary repairs constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment; it instead finds no such breach where repairs were timely made.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment… We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy… Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition… Here, York acted immediately upon being notified… The trial judge did not err in… [finding no] breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Quiet enjoyment protections extend to all issues impacting habitability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly limits the implied warranty of habitability to physical conditions and rejects expanding it to cover security or criminal-activity-related issues. While the opinion recognizes that pervasive criminal activity can breach the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, it does not say that quiet enjoyment protections extend to all issues impacting habitability; instead, it treats habitability and quiet enjoyment as distinct doctrines with different scopes. Thus the case does not support the broad proposition claimed.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
“We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.…

The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.”

Bologna v. Salerno, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 50.raw_text: Bologna v. Salerno, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 503 (1991)
Bologna v. Salerno, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 50.proposition: Breach of quiet enjoyment due to loss of heat.
Bologna v. Salerno, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Commonwealth v. James, a criminal drug trafficking case, not Bologna v. Salerno, and it does not address landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or loss of heat. There is no discussion of breach of quiet enjoyment or habitability issues, so this case cannot support the proposition that there was a breach of quiet enjoyment due to loss of heat.
Bologna v. Salerno, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 50.relevant_excerpt: No excerpt is available because the opinion does not discuss quiet enjoyment, residential tenancies, or loss of heat at all; it concerns criminal liability for cocaine trafficking.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Treble damages for knowing and intentional violations.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion applies statutory provisions that authorize treble (threefold) damages when certain violations occur and the statutory predicates are met. In Section B, the court holds that the landlord’s violation of the security deposit statute triggers liability for “treble damages, interest, costs, and attorney’s fees,” and in Section C it explains that under the Boston rent control ordinance, non‑willful violations are limited to actual overcharge while more culpable conduct allows up to three times the overcharge. Although the opinion focuses more on statutory triggers than on a general scienter standard, it does reflect that enhanced/treble damages are tied to the nature of the violation and, in the ordinance context, to wilfulness.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
We thus agree with the tenant that subsection (7) is applicable to these circumstances and, accordingly, that Young is liable for treble damages, interest, costs, and attorney’s fees.
...
The tenant is, however, entitled to attorney’s fees and costs under the ordinance, as § 9 expressly provides for liability for reasonable attorney’s fees and costs for any person who “receives, or retains any payment of rent, in excess of the maximum lawful rent.” A showing that a violation is neither wilful nor the result of failure to take practicable precautions merely limits the amount of liquidated damages to the amount of the overcharge.

Lindsay v. Bowditch, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 9.raw_text: Lindsay v. Bowditch, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 972 (1985)
Lindsay v. Bowditch, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 9.proposition: Space heater use as tenant expense in breach claims.
Lindsay v. Bowditch, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 9.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with zoning, nonconforming structures, and the standards for granting a variance for a garage location. It does not mention landlord-tenant law, habitability, breach claims, or any issue related to space heater use or tenant expenses. Therefore, it cannot provide authority for the proposition about space heater use as a tenant expense in breach claims.
Lindsay v. Bowditch, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 9.relevant_excerpt: As an alternative avenue of relief, the board of appeals granted Marasco a variance to build a new garage within six and a half feet of the westerly sideline of Surfside Terrace. It did so on the ground that ancient oak trees made the location of the garage closer to the way desirable. That something may be desirable does not, however, rise to the dignity of a hardship. No case has been called to attention in which the location of a tree qualified as “circumstances relating to the soil conditions, shape, or topography of such land.” G. L. c. 40A, § 10.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Landlord’s duty to provide habitable housing.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: Although this is a separate opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part, Quirico, J. explicitly agrees that the old rule of no duty to provide fit premises must be rejected and that landlords of dwelling units have an obligation, for the benefit of tenants, to comply with minimum statutory and code standards of fitness. He further states that by renting, landlords impliedly agree the unit complies with those standards and will be maintained accordingly, which is a clear recognition of a landlord’s duty to provide habitable housing. The disagreement is over the doctrinal framing (implied warranty vs. implied agreement), not over the existence of that duty.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass..raw_text: Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass. 267 (1964)
Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass..proposition: Duty to maintain essential services in rental properties.
Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass..case_name: Municipal Light Commission v. City of Peabody
Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns the governance and fiscal authority over a municipal light department, specifically the allocation and control of funds between the light commission, manager, mayor, city council, treasurer, and auditor. It does not address landlord–tenant law, rental properties, or any duty to maintain essential services in rental housing. Thus, it provides no authority for a general proposition about a duty to maintain essential services in rental properties.
Service v. Serv. Realty Corp., 348 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We conclude therefore that the appropriations necessary to authorize the treasurer to use light department funds for ‘expense of the plant’ may be made by vote of the commission on the budget submitted by the manager. Nevertheless, it is advisable that the city’s budget incorporate the budget of this department of the city. … [T]he management and fiscal operation of the municipal light department of Peabody are vested in the commission and the manager of the plant under St. 1951, c. 286, and G. L. c. 164…”
